title: AB 451
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. Section 21107.8 of the Vehicle Code allows cities or counties to declare privately owned offstreet parking facilities open for public use. These facilities are subject to certain traffic laws, with the option for operators to regulate unauthorized parking. If a city or county allows public use of privately owned offstreet parking facilities, the owner must provide instructions on contesting parking fees and cannot involve the Department of Motor Vehicles in collecting unpaid fees. An ordinance or resolution enacted for offstreet parking facilities must have a notice posted at each entrance warning of public moving vehicle laws and potential parking invoice fees. A parking receipt must also include language about the possibility of a parking invoice fee. Prior to enacting any ordinance or resolution, a public hearing and written notice to the owner and operator of the offstreet parking facility is required. Section 22507.8 can be enforced without an ordinance or resolution, and the department is not obligated to patrol privately owned offstreet parking facilities. Cities or counties authorizing private parking regulation must include dispute resolution procedures in their ordinance. The dispute resolution policy must include specified time periods for notifications, review, and appeal. The administrative hearing process should offer options for in-person or mail hearings, administrative review, and a hearing by a third-party examiner. The examiner must provide an independent, fair, and impartial review, with the authority to allow payment in installments for those unable to pay in full. Incentives based on the number of invoices issued or disputed are prohibited, and there is a cap on parking invoice fees. Measures to prevent private parking regulators from posing as government agencies, including prohibiting the use of government-related terminology in ordinances, resolutions, and parking fee invoices. Invoices must include a statement clarifying they are not issued by the local government.
